description: This recording is from 1968. Jacqueline began composing with her guitar at age 12. “I can’t find my toothbrush / where can it be / the red one is my father’s / the blue one is my mother’s / the yellow one is my brother’s / mine must have gone with the wind.”
Willie Griffin has three known recordings. This one from 1984 is remarkably intimate.
This track from 1960’s vocal trio, “The Invincibles” is a gorgeously somber take on love.

track: Still Got a Way to Fall
description: I need to listen to this track at least 25 more times before I feel comfortable saying more than, “You need to hear this.”
This early live cover of The Impressions’ classic is fantastic. The recording starts with narration that frames the song perfectly. The Chambers Brothers are from Carthage, Mississippi.
I had no idea this band ever existed. I’m convinced that in another reality this track would be the kind of classic that appears on the Remember the Titans soundtrack.

album: Out of the Wilderness / Well Well, Don't Worry 'Bout Me
description: Daptone’s Como Mamas hail from Como, Mississippi. Ester Mae Smith, Angela Taylor, and Della Daniels bring the Gospel with heated authority.
Kamal Keila is also known as “Sudan’s James Brown.” This album is one of the only Sudanese jazz albums in existence. This song pleads for a unified Sudan in a time of conflict.
Blackrock is a fairly mysterious group out of Memphis consisting of four session musicians, two from Stax and two from Hi Records.

album: Ciao My Shining Star - The Songs of Mark Mulcahy
description: This version of Miracle Legion’s, “All For The Best” is one of my favorite covers of all time. This tribute album was recorded to support Mark Mulahy after the sudden passing of his wife, Melissa in 2008.
Singer, guitarist, and songwriter Barabara Lynn defined talent in the 1960’s. She is still active today at 77.
This Sudanese record was originally released in 1980. The Sudanese jazz scene began its decline in 1983 when president Gaafar Nimeiry implemented Sharia law.

album: The Lost Queen Of New Orleans Soul
track: There's A Break In The Road
description: This is thick. Betty’s delivery will stop you dead in your tracks as this boulder of a rhythm kneads your bones against the pavement.
Jackie Shane died this past February. This energy of this recording is aurally tactile. A pioneer transgender performer, she was unjustly labeled as a man throughout her career.

album: What Have You Done, My Brother?
description: 76 year-old Naomi Shelton’s discovery is a recent one. She commands this 2009 Daptone release with a voice steeped in soul.

Very little is known about this 1968 album from Japan’s Harumi Ando. This is one of the coolest songs I’ve ever heard. Apparently Frank Zappa dismissed this record, calling it a “flower-power album.” It is both flowerful and powerful. I struggle to see how that’s a bad thing.

There is so much soul in this track and on this record. Togolese Julie Akofa Akoussah’s voice is incredible. Later in her life, she dedicated herself to early music development and the fight against AIDS.

Rob Roy Reindorf is from Accra, Ghana. Today he can be found at his restaurant, “The Chicken Pepper” back home in Accra. Playing with bands like Benin’s Poly-Rhythmo, he peppered the late 70’s afrobeat scene with funky chicken like this.

artist: Roger Damawuzan, Les As Du Benin
description: Togo’s Roger Damawuzan is known as, “James Brown from Lomé.” The character of his voice can almost be compared to that of Louis Armstrong. This track is other-worldly. This is one of my favorite versions of the spiritual Motherless Child.
The Mandells are unfairly obscure. This track was released on Chicago’s Trans World Sound label and packs a party’s punch.
This track from Brazilian singer Erasmo Carlos is a terrific vibe.

I had a tweet take off and it featured Nat Turner Rebellion’s, “Never Too Late.” An internet stranger let me know they mistook it for this track which samples it. I am so happy they did. Black Milk is from Detroit.
The Yahoos are from Kenya.
I became familiar with this track via Madlib’s tribute on Shades of Blue which doesn’t sample Ronnie’s organ enough if at all.
Mavis is in her mid-twenties in this live recording. The Staple Singers tear the roof off Chicago’s New Nazareth Church.

album: You and Me / Put a Smile on Your Face
description: This Penny & The Quarters song is given new life by Durand Jones & The Indications. This band is quickly establishing its place in the throwback-Soul movement or whatever you want to call it.

These drums are sampled in The Pharcyde’s, “Passin me By,” but the entirety of this track stands strong on its own. I want those horn hits to punctuate my life. The identity of the Skull Snaps was largely unknown for a few decades.
I love discovering that groups are from Chicago when I never knew they were from Chicago. You may recognize this from Big Daddy Kane’s, “Ain’t No Half-Steppin’”
Marlena is confidently restrained in this cover of “California Soul,” backed by the production value of a massive pop hit. This is a great talent doing her job damn well.
This Blue Note recording was one of the first Jazz records I listened to as a young adult. The patience of this track is something I come back to when I need to slow down.
The sampling of William Bell’s, “I Forgot to be Your Lover” is perfectly executed here by The Alchemist.

track: I Forgot To Be Your Lover
description: This is such a beautiful song from Stax’s William Bell. It is sampled in Dilated Peoples’ “Worst comes to Worst.”

album: Don Letts Presents the Mighty Trojan Sound
description: Producer Lloyd “Spiderman” Campbell and singer Claudette are both tucked away beneath relative obscurity. This track is one of my favorites.
Drexel University, Vinyl Me, Please, and Reservoir Media are joint-releasing this full-length for the first time in history. This is my favorite track on the record so far.

This track contains one of the most sampled drum tracks in the history of hip hop. The high school band, “The Honey Drippers” were discovered by singer Roy C. This dense anti-Nixon funk has been a reminder to me of how little has changed since 1973.

album: Ritratto di Mina: I singoli, Vol. 2
description: Originally recorded for the 1963 album, “Stessa Spiaggia Stesso Mare,” this track showcases the vocal talent of Italy’s prolific Mina. She was banned from TV and radio in 1963. If you’re wondering how that turned out, she now has over 70 studio recordings, as recent as 2018.

La Femme makes this Chuck Berry cover their own. This album from 2013 was a gift from a dear friend and is one of the more exciting recordings I listen to with consistency. Fair warning, this bonus track is not on vinyl, but the LP is more than worth it.

album: Been in the Storm So Long - Spirituals & Shouts, Children's Game Songs, and Folktales
track: Jesus Knows All About My Troubles
description: I have no qualms posting this album for a second time. After letting this recording hit you, you’ll see why.

album: The Skeletal Essences of Afro Funk, Vol. 3: 1969-1980
description: Beninese Orchestre Poly Rythmo de Cotonou is also referred to as “Tout Puissant,” or “All Mighty.” This track’s title translates to, “Who knows the future?” “When you come in the world and you have money / It’s not a reason to be proud.”
Eddie Bo is known for the style he brought to the piano, and this funky track features none of it. No New Orleans artist has released as many singles as Eddie other than Fats Domino.

Danyél Waro was born in Réunion, the source of Maloya — a rhythmic style of music established by African and Malagasy slaves on the island. In the early 70’s it was considered a threat to the French imperialist state and subsequently banned. Waro, who is still active today, has been recognized by many indigenous groups for his work reviving the traditions of Réunion.

Rachel Sweet made this record when she was 16. She won an electric garage door opener for her singing at the age of three. This album oscillates between karaoke-production Country, Punk, a Carla Thomas cover, and the straight coolness this track.

album: Have You Been Good to Yourself
track: Have You Been Good to Yourself
description: Home-recorded straight to cassette, this track along with six others were recorded by Johnnie Frierson before he was shipped off to fight in Vietnam. He is the brother of singer Wendy Rene. This album is worth an intentional listen.
Memphis’ Mary Frierson was given the stage name “Wendy Rene” by Otis Redding. She co-wrote this song with her brother Johnnie. “I’ll try to hard my sorrow / I wonder can I hold them til tomorrow.”

The first time I heard this track was on a library-rented CD in 2004. Charles was speaking of things that in my context, I could only hope to understand. 15-odd years later, this piece reminds me that I will never be able to fully understand the experience of a black person in America.
I have no idea what this song is about, but this is another awesome track from 60’s Benin.

My high school contemplation was often set to the tune of Mehldau’s Largo and Elegiac Cycle. This more recent collaboration with drummer Mark Guiliana is markedly more experimental and is precisely the music I was dying to experience back then. Check out the live performance of this track.
This Beninese artist recorded throughout the 60’s and 70’s. Daptone released this compilation in 2011.

album: Saigon Rock & Soul: Vietnamese Classic Tracks 1968-1974
track: Nỗi Buồn Con Gái (The Sadness Of Being A Girl)
description: Carol Kim is regarded as South Vietnam's Queen of Soul. “When we are separated / Our love is full of tears / How long is our youth? / Being a girl is so difficult / Beauty is like smoke and cloud / It will fade to nothingness”

The story of Jackson C. Frank is tragic. His first and only release was recorded with the help of Paul Simon in 1965. This track is from the “Kitchen Tapes” — demos which he recorded in 1997. He died the day after his 56th birthday in 1999.
Sampled in Dilla’s “Fuck the Police.” So happy to have found this record. René is a Belgian composer and violinist and this compilation is a sample gold mine.
This is not Yoko’s “Plastic Ono Band.” You can tell the difference by who is laying on who on the cover...and by whether or not you’re able to listen to it more than once in a 24 hour period.

If your loved one leaves you before going to an Aretha Franklin show and you find yourself hoping Aretha plays a set that will convince them to get back with you, you will definitely be consoled by this George Jackson track.

artist: Philip Glass, Kronos Quartet, Michael Riesman
track: KYOKO'S HOUSE ("stage blood is not enough")
description: Clean uneffected electric guitar sporadically appears on this Philip Glass soundtrack. It adds a raw and unpolished layer to this working picture I have of Glass.
“Don’t huzzle for love, cause it’s gonna come to you.” A gem from Eastern Nigeria’s Apostles.
This 2016 release reignited my inner 2006. New release coming next month.
I sit cross-legged when Serengeti tells stories. He is worth your attention. The letters defined in this song spell FUBU (×4), FILA, BOSS, PACO, JNCO, and USED.
The name, “Niney” refers to the thumb Winston Holness lost in an accident. Niney is one of Jamaica’s most revered producers. “Blood and Fire” was his first hit.
The story of Yup Juns was limited to three years due to the arrest of Shin Joong Hyun by South Korea’s authoritarian regime shortly after the release of their second record in 1975.

album: Negro Prison Songs from the Mississippi State Penitentiary
description: Led by a prisoner named, “22” this work song ends with an observation of the prison industrial complex. “Police get you and you workhouse bound.” Thank Alan Lomax for this 1958 recording.

I cannot put into words how much this performance affects me. I found it yesterday and wish I found it a long time ago. I have cried during every listen of this track. Stop whatever you are doing and give this your time. There is video of this historic album’s recording and its documentary form will be in theaters soon.
The New Orleans strut of this track begs you to move your body and you should oblige it. The Meters are considered by many as originators of funk.

track: Something’s Got A Hold On Me
description: Etta’s rawness is unmistakable. She has such a commanding presence that it is easy to overlook the entire choir on this track.

track: How Long Do I Have To Wait For You?
description: This introduction may be redundant, but it’s worth the risk. Sharon Jones released her first record at 40. Daptone’s first release was a Sharon Jones record. This track is one of the catchiest I have ever heard.

Charles Mingus was my entry point into jazz as an angsty teenage bassist. This composition is an elegy for saxophonist Lester Young. My initial exposure was to this later recording from 1963. The original is titled, “Goodbye Pork Pie Hat” on 1959’s, “Mingus Ah Um.”

album: Sam Cooke With The Soul Stirrers
track: Nearer To Thee - Live at the Shrine
description: This live performance (The Great 1955 Shrine Concert) features an utterly untethered Sam Cooke and Paul Foster. The climax of this performance is hair-raising-ly palpable. It decidedly steps miles over the fine line Gospel music was walking at the time.

album: One Night Stand - Sam Cooke Live At The Harlem Square Club, 1963
track: Bring It on Home to Me
description: RCA Victor slept on this record for 22 years. It didn’t fit the likeness of Sam Cooke that they were spinning to white audiences across the country. If this doesn’t hit you square in the feels, you are a dead person.
The hurried lyrical rhythm of this track perfectly describes what is both an adorably playful infatuation, and an infinitely desirable state of elation. From Detroit’s own Queen of Soul.

I don’t know what to do with this. I cried when I heard this song, then cried harder when I watched the music video. David Ruffin is sampled perfectly by producer Your Old Droog. It is supremely beautiful. This mixtape is amazing.
This album was released 13 years after Ruffin (The Temptations) died in 1991. It was recorded in the late 60’s. It was sampled in Westside Gunn’s, “Summer Slam 88.”
The sample closing out Earl’s, “Some Rap Songs,” and a prime piece from Hugh Masekela, the, “Father of South African jazz.”
The first producer Lester Bullock worked with was Lee “Scratch” Perry, who recommended the name change to, “Dillinger.” That is reason enough to listen to this song.

album: Been in the Storm So Long - Spirituals & Shouts, Children's Game Songs, and Folktales
description: This Folkways recording is of an isolated community living on Johns Island, SC — an area referred to by Alan Lomax as, “One of the heartlands of American music.” The entire record is shockingly potent, but this specific performance by Laura Rivers is exceptional.

album: Kenya Special, Vol. 2 (Selected East African Recordings from the 1970’s & 80’s)
description: I found myself listening to this weekly throughout 2018. “This world is coming to an end. This world is coming to an end. I can feel it. You can feel it. We all can feel it.”

album: Beautiful Rivers and Mountains: The Psychedelic Rock Sound of South Korea’s Shin Joong Hyun 1958-1974
description: Shin is referred to as Korea’s, “Godfather of Rock.” He protested a ‘72 military dictatorship and was imprisoned. His music was subsequently banned until the ‘80s.

album: New Skin For The Old Ceremony
description: Leonard Cohen makes me feel nostalgic about things that I have no business pretending to remember.
“And you think your country is a great democracy, Well they just killed your priest for helping folks like me.”
I don’t know anything about Anika, but this song makes me feel like the best kind of vampire. It uses tension remarkably well.
This is a tribute to O.D.B.’s “Snakes.” It will make you wish there was a complete Lee Fields cover of the sampled, “I’ll Never Do You Wrong” by Joe Tex.
No one needs my opinion of Frank. “You don’t know how little you matter until you’re all alone...”
I used to find this style of ‘80s production un-listenable, but this Trinidad & Tobago release from 1984 has made me second guess that notion entirely.

extra_links: NPR: The Tragic Turn Of The Frightnrs' First — And Last — Record
description: Easily mistaken for 1968 Kingston, Jamaica. In reality it is 2016 Jamaica, Queens. This is, in a sense, a goodbye letter from singer Dan Klein. Dan succumbed to ALS three months prior to this Daptone release — hours after attending a Sharon Jones performance.
Limiting this vibe to 78 seconds is unfair to anyone that hears it. “Did I s...s...stutter, G?”
This track makes my face look like I am feeling a wad of bread dough in that game where you blindly stick your hand in a box and try to figure out what’s inside.
This is the sort of music I need more of.

track: Anyone Who Knows What Love Is (Will Understand)
description: Grab that special someone and slow dance with them. You don’t do it enough.

The first time I spent over $50 on a record. This song means everything to me. I found it when I first started developing my own musical taste. The single for “How Long” was the first Jamaican record to feature a string arrangement (overdubbed in UK release).
The song that got me into reggae. Good luck landing a copy of this version. I haven’t.

album: Bunny “Striker” Lee’s Full Up: Early Reggae Productions 1968-72
description: Find an alley, headphones on, hood up, and dance that pain away.

album: I Love The Way You Love
description: Name that sample. This is better.

album: Elizabeth Cotten, Volume 3: When I’m Gone
description: Dim the lights, sit in that chair you never sit in, light a cigarette, put this on loop, and close your eyes.
Apparently this song is a bluegrass standard, but I think it is actually everything.

album: Every Time I Feel the Spirit
description: Paul Robeson is always bigger than you think he is. He changed the words that he had sung countless times to ones that marked the spirit of his defiance. Boldly defying injustice while exercising remarkable kindness and compassion, Paul resounded in deep baritone across the nation. Everyone should learn the story of Paul Robeson.

track: Ain't Got No - I Got Life
description: Words do not describe the power of this song as it is performed here by Nina.

Donny effortlessly floats on top of a heavy D’Angelo-esque cadence in a straight-out-of-the-saloon-you-wish-existed live performance. In no reality would John Lennon come close to this. Another performance of this song is sampled in Chance’s “Juice”.
Shaking a hand during the chorus is impossible when they are both straight up in the air.
This is my anthem when I feel rambunctious.

album: Things That Happen At Day // Things That Happen At Night
description: This guy raps like I think. “I will become a squiggle in the string of quotients.”
This is Ravyn’s most popular track on Spotify for a reason. Probably because people have sex.
However you want define this, you should prefix it with “Damn good”. Entirely percussive. Thank Chicago’s International Anthem.

artist: Fela Ransome Kuti & His Koola Lobitos
description: Early Fela. I dance to this at least once a week in my socks.
Tony Allen holds this whole record down. LEGIT’s verse on this track demonstrates just how seamlessly rap and afrobeat can fit together.
Xenia is daringly gritty in rhythm and vocal play. Looks like it’s about time for a new release too. Fingers crossed.
If ‘06 Bonnaroo Andrew Bird signed to Stones Throw and used sidechain compression, it wouldn’t work. This does. “Sink” is a great record too.
Opening track from my A24 Film's soundtrack. My karate is sick.
Ethiopian music has a rich history worth exploration. Just happened upon this one.
Remember all caps when you spell the man name...and when you refer to THE BEST TRACK OF ALL TIME.
NONAME × 13 PHOELIX × 7 CHICAGO × 100. These two made my NYE special.

Jonah Hill’s new flick “Mid90s” uses the climax of this Hungarian anthem to bring out the feels in its trailer. Frank Ocean sings over a sample of this at the end of New Slaves. Ye should have sampled the last refrain...

Nun. Composer. Genius. In the late 60’s, the proceeds of Emahoy’s work benefitted an orphanage. In 1984 she fled religious persecution from the Ethiopian government. She is 95 years old and there is a foundation in her name helping children study music.
An all-too-familiar narrative as it was in 2001. “Now tell me who protects me from you?”

track: Pow-wow Dance (Flathead) - Alan Fox and Lawrence Kiskotagan
description: Library of Congress Catalogue recording from 1959. Pow-wow music should be revered. It’s still being made today. Do yourself a favor and YouTube it.
80’s Somali Funk. Say no more.

album: Sweet as Broken Dates: Lost Somali Tapes from the Horn of Africa
track: Rag Waa Nacab Iyo Nasteexo (Men are Cruel and Kind) - Aamina Camaari
description: Try not to dance. This whole compilation is fairly lo-fi and catchy as hell.
Yes, Kanye sampled this. Discovering that I owned the original was a happy accident courtesy of Numero Group.
The music industry treated Lee poorly. He never saw appreciation before his death in ‘97. His work is hard to find with physical copies being appropriately insanely-priced.
Has he gone soft? I don’t care. That hook is gold and it frames Chance’s modest reflection on ambition perfectly. Happy holidays.
